2970/A0/05/805/003.status_value: Met. 537 081 children (106% of target) in the 14 severely affected districts were vaccinated through measles and polio immunization campaigns.
2970/A0/05/805/003.indicator_name: Children age 6-59 months in the severely affected districts vaccinated for measles
2970/A0/05/805/003.headline: Disaster resilient cold chain system in 22 earthquake-affected districts has been established  contributing to restoring damaged cold chain equipment and enhancing disaster preparedness. An estimated 126 364 children benefitted from this initiative to prevent vaccine preventable diseases through the Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI) and immunization campaigns.

2970/A0/05/805/003.status_value: Met. 406 181 children under five (145% of target) in the 14 severely affected districts ensured access to live-saving services for diarrhoea and cholera.
2970/A0/05/805/003.indicator_name: Children under 5 in the severely affected districts have access to life saving services for diarrhea

An estimated 126 364 children benefitted from this initiative to prevent vaccine preventable diseases through the Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI) and immunization campaigns.

2970/A0/05/805/003.status_value: Met. 46 522 mothers and newborns (111% of target) in the severely affected districts were reached with essential and emergency care.
2970/A0/05/805/003.indicator_name: Mothers and new-borns in the severely affected districts reached with essential emergency care

An estimated 126 364 children benefitted from this initiative to prevent vaccine preventable diseases through the Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI) and immunization campaigns.

2970/A0/05/805/002.status_value: On-track. 655 910 earthquake-affected people reached with safe water for drinking  cooking  and personal hygiene through water trucking and point-of use treatment including water kits and water treatment products. An additional 455 613 people reached with sustained water services.
2970/A0/05/805/002.indicator_name: People in the severely affected districts with access to a sufficient quantity of water of appropriate quality for drinking  cooking and personal hygiene
2970/A0/05/805/002.headline: Capacity assessment and capacity building of communities and stakeholders on resilient WASH as part of building back better was an integral part of the work.

2970/A0/05/805/002.status_value: On-track. 279 263 people have access to emergency and sustained sanitation.
2970/A0/05/805/002.indicator_name: People in the severely affected districts with access to adequate sanitation and hand washing facilities
2970/A0/05/805/002.headline: Capacity assessment and capacity building of communities and stakeholders on resilient WASH as part of building back better was an integral part of the work.

2970/A0/05/805/002.status_value: On-track. 82 000 households reached with the provision of family hygiene kits and 631 992 people oriented on hygiene education.
2970/A0/05/805/002.indicator_name: People reached with hygiene education materials and interpersonal communication
2970/A0/05/805/002.headline: Capacity assessment and capacity building of communities and stakeholders on resilient WASH as part of building back better was an integral part of the work.

2970/A0/05/805/007.status_value: Met. 1 000 000 people (100% of target) in severely affected districts were reached with critical life-saving information.
2970/A0/05/805/007.indicator_name: People in severely affected districts are reached with critical life-saving information
2970/A0/05/805/007.headline: Community-based communication and social mobilization interventions to promote disaster risk reduction and issues like safe migration and child participation reached 26 000 adolescents and youth helping them become more resilient to future disasters.

2970/A0/05/805/006.status_value: Out of three key action planned for 2016  two are underway and one has not yet been initiated. Five Key recommendations agreed with 18 Key Actions planned  of which three are planned for 2016 and 15 up to end 2017. Source: Evaluation of UNICEF's Response and Recovery Efforts to the Gorkha Earthquake in Nepal ¿ UNICEF Evaluation Management Response Plan.
2970/A0/05/805/006.indicator_name: Evaluation of UNICEF earthquake response completed
2970/A0/05/805/006.headline: The Evaluation of UNICEF's Response and Recovery Efforts to the Gorkha Earthquake indicated that UNICEF's initial response was quick and characterized by significant initial field presence and early mobilisation of prepositioned contingency supplies  funds and partners. Through HAC appeal  US$ 120 million have been fully funded until end of 2017.

2970/A0/05/805/006.indicator_name: HPM indicators for all programme sectors are developed  shared and integrated in UNICEF earthquake emergency response plan
2970/A0/05/805/006.headline: The Evaluation of UNICEF's Response and Recovery Efforts to the Gorkha Earthquake indicated that UNICEF's initial response was quick and characterized by significant initial field presence and early mobilisation of prepositioned contingency supplies  funds and partners. Through HAC appeal  US$ 120 million have been fully funded until end of 2017.

2970/A0/05/805/006.status_value: Met. Five key actions from After Action Review (AAR) continued from 2015 and 2 planned for 2016.
2970/A0/05/805/006.indicator_name: Critical learning and lessons from ongoing humanitarian response captured and shared with the concerned to strengthen future Nepal earthquake response
2970/A0/05/805/006.headline: The Evaluation of UNICEF's Response and Recovery Efforts to the Gorkha Earthquake indicated that UNICEF's initial response was quick and characterized by significant initial field presence and early mobilisation of prepositioned contingency supplies  funds and partners. Through HAC appeal  US$ 120 million have been fully funded until end of 2017.

2970/A0/05/805/005.status_value: On-track. 1 347 children out of the 2 500 children (54% of target) expected to have SAM have been admitted to OTP (Outpatient Therapeutic Program) centres. These children were identified after screening more than 370 000 children aged 6-59 months for acute malnutrition  which is about 80% of children of that age group.
2970/A0/05/805/005.indicator_name: Children age 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition in severely affected districts who are admitted to therapeutic care
2970/A0/05/805/005.headline: 755  000 children under five and pregnant and lactating women received high impact  evidence based nutrition interventions. A total of 66 024 individuals were treated in OTCs and TSFC.

2970/A0/05/805/005.status_value: Met. 326 091 children aged 6-59 months (101% of target) were provided with micronutrient powders. This was more than 100% of the total population of that age group based on HMIS data. However  the expected result of the cluster was reaching 323 000 children. Thus  the cluster exceeded the expected result in this intervention.
2970/A0/05/805/005.indicator_name: Children age 6-59 months in severely affected districts who receive multiple micronutrient powders to improve their diets and prevent nutritional deficiencies
2970/A0/05/805/005.headline: 755  000 children under five and pregnant and lactating women received high impact  evidence based nutrition interventions. A total of 66 024 individuals were treated in OTCs and TSFC.

2970/A0/05/805/005.status_value: Met. 157 660 mothers and caretakers of children aged 0-23 months (125% of target) were given guidance regarding the proper breastfeeding and complementary feeding practices. This was more than 100% of the population of that age group. The expected result of the cluster was reaching 126 000 children. Thus  the cluster exceeded the expected result in this intervention.
2970/A0/05/805/005.indicator_name: Mother of children 0-23 months old living in the severely affected districts who receive information and counselling on breastfeeding and complementary feeding
2970/A0/05/805/005.headline: 755  000 children under five and pregnant and lactating women received high impact  evidence based nutrition interventions. A total of 66 024 individuals were treated in OTCs and TSFC.

2970/A0/05/805/004.status_value: On-track. 158 478 (96% of the target) parents and children have been provided with psychosocial support including psychosocial first aid (PFA) and focused psychosocial counseling.
2970/A0/05/805/004.indicator_name: Children in the severely affected districts received community-based psychosocial support as well as specialized psychosocial service
2970/A0/05/805/004.headline: Emergency response and recovery efforts have contributed to strengthening the national child protection system. Anti-trafficking initiatives after the earthquake have contributed in increased awareness on trafficking activities among communities and stronger border surveillance for prevention of trafficking.

2970/A0/05/805/004.status_value: Met. 161 877 (113% of the target) people in the severely-affected districts reached by community groups to prevent and address violence  abuse and exploitation  including GBV and trafficking. 956 women  girls  boys and men have been prevented from being trafficked.
2970/A0/05/805/004.indicator_name: People in the severely-affected districts reached by community groups to prevent and address violence  abuse and exploitation  including GBV and trafficking
2970/A0/05/805/004.headline: Emergency response and recovery efforts have contributed to strengthening the national child protection system. Anti-trafficking initiatives after the earthquake have contributed in increased awareness on trafficking activities among communities and stronger border surveillance for prevention of trafficking.

2970/A0/05/805/004.status_value: Met. 100% of the identified cases  i.e. 379 (113 unaccompanied and 266 separated) children  out of which 353 were reunified with their families and 26 children placed in alternative care.
2970/A0/05/805/004.indicator_name: Children identified as separated or unaccompanied as a result of the earthquake are reunited with their families or placed in proper alternative care
2970/A0/05/805/004.headline: Emergency response and recovery efforts have contributed to strengthening the national child protection system. Anti-trafficking initiatives after the earthquake have contributed in increased awareness on trafficking activities among communities and stronger border surveillance for prevention of trafficking.

2970/A0/05/602/002.status_value: In priority districts  100% vitamin A coverage  92% iodized salt coverage  84% multiple nutrient coverage (disaggregation by disability and HIV affected population not possible at this time).

2970/A0/05/602/002.headline: Maintained high standard coverage of essential nutrition services such as vitamin A (90%)  iodised salt (>80%) and iron folic acid (80%)  as well as management of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) amongst children under five years in line with SPHERE standard including children with disability and HIV affected.

2970/A0/05/805/009.status_value: On-track. 17 press releases issued  23 Situation Reports produced  more than 50 human interest stories produced. 55 per cent increase in the number of likes on UNICEF Nepal Facebook page since 25 April 2015. Last year  the increase was 42 per cent of the same time period. 176 per cent increase in the number of follower of UNICEF Nepal Twitter account since 25 April 2015.
2970/A0/05/805/009.indicator_name: Information on UNICEF response to Nepal earthquake emergency is shared widely through media statements/ news notes  press releases / situation reports and social media feeds.
2970/A0/05/805/009.headline: UNICEF ensured the continuous feed of high quality multimedia materials  especially around the one-year mark of the 2015 earthquake to draw the attention of donors as well as the public to the needs of children in earthquake-affected districts in Nepal  which helped raise funds appealed through HAC.

2970/A0/05/805/008.indicator_name: Vulnerable people including persons with disabilities  older persons  widows  and Dalit children under 5 in 19 severely affected districts receive an emergency top-up to their regular social assistance grants.
2970/A0/05/805/008.headline: 260 000 children under five in severely affected districts benefitted from earthquake recovery cash transfer. The programme was built on and implemented by Government mechanism with UNICEF's technical and financial support and is a follow-up to 2015 first phase that reached 434 000 vulnerable population in affected districts.

2970/A0/05/602/004.status_value: 9 out of 25 targeted districts have developed multi-sectoral gender-sensitive  costed ECD plans.
2970/A0/05/602/004.indicator_name: # of District Development Committees with an annual multi-sectoral  gender-sensitive ECD plan (incorporating stimulation  education  health  HIV and AIDS  nutrition  protection and WASH interventions tapping local resources ¿ linking with CFLG)
2970/A0/05/602/004.headline: With continuous advocacy from UNICEF and partners  Early Childhood Development was recognized as basic child right in new constitution promulgated on September 2015. Further  free and compulsory basic education including one year of pre-primary (early childhood education) was ensured in new education law amendment and new education sector plan.

2970/A0/05/601/002.status_value: Implementation of Multisectoral Nutrition Plan (MSNP) has been initiated in 16 districts and will be scaled up in additional 12 districts by mid-2017.
2970/A0/05/601/002.indicator_name: Multi-Sectoral Nutrition Plan supported by a Multi-Sector Nutrition Information System adapted locally and implemented in normal and humanitarian situations
2970/A0/05/601/002.headline: Government of Nepal increased its annual budget allocation by 10 per cent for national nutrition programme  equivalent to US$ 2 million for its current fiscal year. In addition  EU and UNICEF collaboration allocated 27.7 million Euros for Multi-sectoral Nutrition Plan (MSNP) implementation in 28 districts from 2016 to 2019.

2970/A0/05/805/001.status_value: On-track. 159 900 children (87% of target) in severely affected districts have accessed temporary learning centers.
2970/A0/05/805/001.indicator_name: Children in severely affected districts accessing temporary learning centers
2970/A0/05/805/001.headline: UNICEF supported children in earthquake-affected districts to access quality education  focusing on comprehensive school safety and resilience. 141 744 children benefitted from receiving education supplies  and 2 775 teachers  Early Childhood Development (ECD) facilitators  and SMC members were trained on psychosocial support  school safety and disaster risk reduction.
